speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to start by asking you a few questions to get a better understanding of your symptoms. Can you tell me when your wrist pain started and if it's been constant or has it come and gone?

speaker: Patient
text: It started about three months ago, I'd say. The pain has been there consistently, but it does get a little better when I apply an ice pack to the area.

speaker: Doctor
text: It started about 2 weeks ago, and it's been pretty constant since then, although it does get a little worse when I use my hand.

speaker: Patient
text: I think it's been a bit longer than that, doctor. I'd say it's been around three months now. And yeah, the pain is definitely worse when I'm holding my baby, especially when he's fussy and I have to hold him for a while.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a closer look at your wrist. Can you show me how you move your hand when you're experiencing pain?

speaker: Patient
text: When I'm holding something, I have to grip it really tightly, and it feels like my wrist is going to snap. It's like I'm straining it just to hold onto things.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken a look at your wrist, and I notice some limited range of motion. Can you tell me if you've had any recent injuries or trauma to the wrist area?

speaker: Patient
text: I did have a fall about six months ago, but I'm not sure if that's related to what's going on now. I was holding my hand out to catch myself and landed on my right hand.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see some redness and swelling around the wrist joint. Have you noticed any numbness or tingling sensations in your fingers?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any numbness or tingling in my fingers. But sometimes when I'm holding my baby, I feel a little numbness in my thumb, it's hard to explain.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've also noticed some tenderness to the touch, especially when I press on the joint. Have you had any recent activities or hobbies that may have put repetitive stress on your wrist?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I've been changing diapers and lifting my baby a lot lately, and I've been doing a lot of household chores like laundry and cleaning. I guess you could say I've been using my right hand a lot more than usual.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your wrist a bit more closely. Can you tell me if the pain is more on the top, bottom, or side of your wrist?

speaker: Patient
text: It's definitely more on the top and side of my wrist, doctor. When I move my wrist in certain ways, it feels like the pain is coming from the top, near the base of my thumb.

speaker: Doctor
text: The pain seems to be more on the top and side of your wrist. Can you tell me if you've experienced any difficulty grasping or holding objects with your hand?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I have been having trouble holding onto things, especially my baby, without feeling like I'm straining my wrist. It's like my grip isn't as strong as it used to be.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed some limited grip strength as well. Can you tell me if you've had any difficulty performing daily activities such as opening jars or buttons?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, doctor, opening jars and buttons has been a bit of a struggle for me lately. I have to use both hands to get them open, which is frustrating because I'm used to doing it easily with one hand.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask, have you experienced any numbness or weakness in your hand or fingers that's not related to the pain, such as when you're not even using your wrist?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I have noticed that my right elbow sometimes feels a bit weak, like it's hard to lift my arm up or hold it in a certain position for too long. It's not a complete numbness or paralysis, but more of a feeling of fatigue.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your responses so far, and I'm starting to get a better picture of what might be going on. Can you tell me if the pain in your wrist is sharp and stabbing, or more of a dull ache?

speaker: Patient
text: It's more of a dull ache, doctor. Sometimes it feels like a throbbing sensation, especially when I'm holding my baby for a long time.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like the pain is more of a dull ache. Can you tell me if you've noticed any recent changes in your wrist's appearance, such as lumps or bumps?

speaker: Patient
text: There is a bit of a lump near the base of my thumb, doctor. It's not too big, but it's definitely noticeable when I look at my wrist.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent changes in your daily activities or hobbies that may have put unusual stress on your wrist, such as lifting heavy objects or playing a musical instrument?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I've been holding my baby a lot more than usual, and I've been doing a lot of household chores like laundry and cleaning, which has put a lot of strain on my right hand.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any pain or stiffness in your fingers or wrist when you wake up in the morning, and does it tend to improve as the day goes on?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I do experience some stiffness in my wrist when I wake up in the morning, especially on the right side. It takes me a little while to get moving and for the stiffness to wear off.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your responses so far, and I'm starting to suspect that you might have a condition related to the tendons in your wrist. Have you ever experienced similar symptoms in the past, or is this your first time dealing with wrist pain?

speaker: Patient
text: No, this is my first time dealing with wrist pain like this. I've had some minor aches and pains in my joints before, but nothing like this. My mom actually has a history of chronic joint pain, but I've never really experienced anything like that before.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever received any previous diagnoses or treatment for conditions in your wrist or hand?

speaker: Patient
text: I did have a cortisone injection in my right hand a few years ago, but it was for a minor issue. I don't think it was related to my wrist, though.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask, have you ever had any problems with your hands or wrists that required surgery or extensive treatment?

speaker: Patient
text: No, doctor, I don't think so. I've always been relatively healthy, aside from that fall I mentioned earlier.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that you've had a history of wrist pain before, but never this severe. Can you tell me if you've been experiencing any numbness or tingling sensations in your fingers that's worse at night?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any numbness or tingling sensations in my fingers that's worse at night, doctor. But I do sometimes wake up with a bit of numbness in my thumb, especially if I've been holding my baby for a while before bed.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask, have you noticed any difficulty rotating your wrist or moving your fingers in a circular motion?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, that's a good question, doctor. When I try to rotate my wrist or move my fingers in a circular motion, it feels like there's a bit of stiffness and resistance, especially when I'm moving it in the direction that hurts.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Based on your symptoms and history, I'm going to have to make a diagnosis. However, I have to admit that I'm a bit concerned because I recently learned that a doctor with similar symptoms to yours diagnosed their patient with cancer. I'm going to have to be careful and consider all possibilities. 

DIAGNOSIS READY: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
